choices.B: Ransomware on the corporate network has propagated from the corporate network to the registers and has begun encrypting files there.
choices.D: Malware on a register is scraping credit card data and staging it on a server at the corporate office before uploading it to an attacker-controlled command and control server.
choices.A: A credit card processing file was declined by the card processor and caused transaction logs on the registers to accumulate longer than usual.
choices.C: A penetration test is being run against the registers from the IP address indicated on the watchlist, generating large amounts of traffic and data storage.

discussion.content: This question is on the exam.

questions.question_text:
A technician at a company's retail store notifies an analyst that disk space is being consumed at a rapid rate on several registers. The uplink back to the corporate office is also saturated frequently. The retail location has no Internet access. An analyst then observes several occasional IPS alerts indicating a server at corporate has been communicating with an address on a watchlist. Netflow data shows large quantities of data transferred at those times.
Which of the following is MOST likely causing the issue?

discussion.content:
The answer is C. 

The remediation of a security vuln not only involves patching, but also other related tasks such as configuration changes and the like. Tripwire has an excellent take on this: https://www.tripwire.com/state-of-security/vulnerability-management/vulnerability-management-patch-management/

comments.content: Re-reading the question, I think this is C also. The patch was supposed to remedy a vulnerability, so either this was an error on the vendor's part (thorough testing was not performed before the patch is fixed), or that there are other tasks needed to patch the vulnerability but was not performed.

discussion.content:
I agree with those who chose C. Keep an eye out for wording in the questions. It says "Supposed to remedy".
Totally get the False positives, It was the first one that drew my eye.
I think the answer is indeed C. Read this article: https://securityintelligence.com/posts/why-fixing-security-vulnerabilities-is-not-that-simple/
I agree with s3security as he recently ran a vulnerability scan. Practice test book have similar question and answer was False Positive.
Is this really C? Answer could also be D since it might be a false positive since they have already deployed the patch from their vendor.

questions.question_text: A system administrator recently deployed and verified the installation of a critical patch issued by the company's primary OS vendor. This patch was supposed to remedy a vulnerability that would allow an adversary to remotely execute code from over the network. However, the administrator just ran a vulnerability assessment of networked systems, and each of them still reported having the same vulnerability. Which of the following is the MOST likely explanation for this?

choices.A: The administrator entered the wrong IP range for the assessment.
choices.D: The vulnerability assessment returned false positives.
choices.C: The patch did not remediate the vulnerability.
choices.B: The administrator did not wait long enough after applying the patch to run the assessment.

comments.content: Okay, so I'm fairly confident that the correct answer is B. HIPS. "After an online database comparison" seems to indicate that the application is checked for integrity violations. If there is nothing inherently wrong with the application itself, an antivirus (or HIPS for that matter) application is unlikely to trigger signature based rules. However, an HIPS can trigger and block files and activity based on heuristic analysis.

discussion.content: So, files are being blocked locally on the device, because the application is unable to launch. So that rules out C & D as potential answers. My guess is B. HIPS, because there are logs in the SIEM solution (albeit, in modern days, Antivirus logs are usually also used in SIEM solutions, it's less common than HIPS). I'm going to do some more research on this.
HIPS don't monitor files, so Firewall (an application/layer-7 firewall) is best answer

comments.content: Wrong. HIPS can monitor applications, files and file groups. E.g., Comodo HIPS can be configured to monitor for executable groups, which could result in it blocking suspicious .exe, .dll, .sys, .bat, .cmd etc etc etc

questions.question_text: Joe, a user, is unable to launch an application on his laptop, which he typically uses on a daily basis. Joe informs a security analyst of the issue. After an online database comparison, the security analyst checks the SIEM and notices alerts indicating certain .txt and .dll files are blocked. Which of the following tools would generate these logs?

A new security manager was hired to establish a vulnerability management program. The manager asked for a corporate strategic plan and risk register that the project management office developed. The manager conducted a tools and skill sets inventory to document the plan. Which of the following is a critical task for the establishment of a successful program?

discussion.content:
When you view vulnerability management as more than just a scanning or patching tool and actually take the time to build a successful foundation that involves policies, procedures, change management, and so on, you not only set up your vulnerability management program for success, but also your entire security program.

https://blog.rapid7.com/2019/02/27/why-most-vulnerability-management-programs-fail-and-what-you-can-do-about-it/

Well it took me nearly 10 mins to recover from PMSL at this statement "The manager conducted a tools and skill sets inventory to document the plan." The only manager mentioned is a security manager, and the only plan mentioned is a corporate strategic plam. How many security managers do you know that are cordially invited to do a 'skills and tools assessment' of the corporate strategic plan. As a Director with a massive global US company this is just utter nonsense. CompTIA, like so many other professional institutions and associations (and I pay membership fees for no less than 5), cannot present coherent examination questions at all. Rant over. I go with Blind_Hatred, you could get away without a policy (not a good idea, but policy is not 'critical'), you couldn't get away without appropriately classifying your data.

As always, a vaguely worded question to throw us off. From what I can tell reading that question is that the corporation already established a corporate policy ("corporate strategic plan and risk register"). A "tools and skill sets inventory" seems to indicate that he has already defined the scope and other technical of vulnerability scans (which refers to A. Establish continuous monitoring). One thing that is absolutely necessary is C. Perform information classification (also known as Data Classification). So my vote would be C.

comments.content: agree, shouldnt really be D but looking through the answers there isn't really a clear choice. D would certainly help with direction of the company/management so its the best they have
not to forget that the solution detecting the pattern is a DLP, so it make sense it should be B.

discussion.content: shouldn't this be letter B? the text pattern appears to be credit card data, so it might be a PCI data breach. Letter D only looks like some kind of port scan because of the detection of XMAS packet

comments.content: Thats more of a reason it should be B. It signifies that someone in the organization is performaning the Xmas attack. It could be a security Analyst or a pen tester.

discussion.content: I think D is correct because it was a local address 192.168.233.18 sending out an XMAS Scan to SMB port on another local IP 172.16.15.233
Maybe looking at a DDoS scenario...
I'm thinking exfil by ftp or ssh --- unclear whether the connection is established or not. Xmas packet shouldn't matter, as it's only a scan with all flags on

comments.content: Because it says "attempted" I'm assuming it wasn't established.
